Description: MINNESOTA IS SEEKING FUNDING TO SUPPORT WORK BY THE MIDWEST BAT HUB NORTH AMERICAN BAT MONITORING PROGRAM TO ANALYZE AND SUMMARIZE PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED INFORMATION ON BATS IN MINNESOTA.

THE 1836 TRUST LAND IS HOME TO A LARGE NUMBER OF BAT SPECIES, INCLUDING THE NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT (MYOTIS SEPTENTRIONALIS), THAT IS OF GREAT CONCERN AND HAS RECENTLY BEEN PROPOSED FOR RECLASSIFICATION AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS). THE ARRIVAL OF WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME (WNS) INTO THE MIDWEST HAS DEVASTATED MANY BAT SPECIES, REDUCING SOME POPULATIONS BY 90 . BATS HOLD NOT ONLY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN THE ECOSYSTEM OF MICHIGAN THROUGH THEIR ROLES IN POLLINATION, INSECT CONTROL, AND IN THE CYCLE OF NUTRIENTS, BUT ALSO WITHIN THE OJIBWE CULTURE, FEATURING IN MANY STORIES AND LESSONS. THE BAY MILLS INDIAN COMMUNITY (BMIC) WILL PARTNER WITH NORTH AMERICAN BAT MONITORING PROGRAM (NABAT) THROUGH THIS GRANT TO FIRST USE ACOUSTIC MONITORING DEVICES THEN HANDS-ON CAPTURES TO MONITOR BAT POPULATIONS WITHIN THE 1836 TREATY CEDED TERRITORY. THIS WILL ALLOW THE COLLECTION ON HEALTH OF THE BAT POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT THIS AREA AND TESTING FOR THE EXTENT OF EXPOSURE TO P. DESTRUCTANS OR WNS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT AND PARTNERSHIP, INFORMATION CAN BE SHARED THAT WILL HELP TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND THE MIDWEST.
WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME GRANTS TO STATES AND TRIBES 2022   WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES

SEVERE DECLINES IN CERTAIN POPULATIONS OF MYOTIS VELIFER IN THE PATH OF THE INVADING WHITE NOSE SYNDROME (WNS) DISEASE FRONT SUGGEST THIS DISEASE MAY BE A THREAT TO THE SPECIES LONG TERM PERSISTENCE IN THE UNITED STATES. WHITE NOSE SYNDROME IS CAUSED BY A COLD LOVING FUNGUS, PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS (PD), THAT GROWS ON THE SKIN OF HIBERNATING BATS DURING PERIODS OF DEEP TORPOR IN THE COLD SEASON.SUSTAINED HIBERNATION IS APPARENTLY CRITICAL FOR WNS PROGRESSION, THUS BATS THAT EXPERIENCE SHORTER, MILDER WINTERS MAY HAVE LOWER RISK OF MORTALITY DUE TO WNS.MYOTIS VELIFER ARE DISTRIBUTED FROM CENTRAL KANSAS, THROUGH SOUTHWESTERN US AND MEXICO TO HONDURAS, SPANNING A BROAD CLIMATE GRADIENT WHERE BATS IN THE NORTHERN EXTENT EXPERIENCE LONGER, COLDER WINTERS THAN IN THE SOUTHERN EXTENT, WHERE THE COLD SEASON IS RELATIVELY SHORTER AND MILDER. THUS, THE POTENTIAL RISK OF WNS RELATED DECLINES IN MYOTIS VELIFER POPULATIONS MAY BE EXPECTED TO VARY ACROSS THEIR RANGE DEPENDING ON WHERE THEY OVERWINTER.MYOTIS VELIFER WEST OF CENTRAL TEXAS ARE COMMON AND ABUNDANT IN THE SUMMER BUT APPEAR TO BE MIGRATORY IN THE WINTER. HOWEVER, WHERE THESE SEASONAL POPULATIONS OVERWINTER IS LARGELY UNKNOWN.RECENT EMERGENCE OF WNS IN LARGE MYOTIS VELIFER HIBERNACULA  HAS INCREASED THE URGENCY TO UNDERSTAND MIGRATORY CONNECTIVITY AMONG POPULATIONS.TO ADDRESS THIS NEED, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH MANAGEMENT AUTHORITIES IN MYOTIS VELIFER RANGE STATES, WE PROPOSE TO USE POPULATION GENETIC APPROACHES TO MAP MIGRATORY AND GENETIC CONNECTIVITY AMONG POPULATIONS ACROSS THE US RANGE TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS IN RESPONSE TO WNS.GENETIC SAMPLES FROM MYOTIS VELIFER WILL BE COLLECTED AND GENOTYPED FROM ACROSS THEIR DISTRIBUTION IN THEIR SUMMER AND WINTER RANGES. GENETIC STRUCTURE WILL BE COMPARED WITHIN AND BETWEEN SEASONS, ASSIGNING BATS SAMPLED IN THE SUMMER TO THEIR COLD SEASON POPULATIONS. IN ADDITION, BATS CAPTURED FOR THIS STUDY IN BOTH SEASONS WILL BE TESTED FOR THE PRESENCE OF THE FUNGUS THAT CAUSES WHITE NOSE SYNDROME TO ASSESS EXPOSURE AND MAP PD DISTRIBUTION IN THIS POPULATION.WE ANTICIPATE THAT THE RESULTS OF OUR STUDY WILL FILL CRITICAL INFORMATION GAPS REGARDING MIGRATORY CONNECTIVITY AND DISEASE RISK ACROSS THE MYOTIS VELIFER RANGE IN THE SOUTHWESTERN US. THE RESULTS OF THIS RESEARCH WILL BE CRITICAL FOR IDENTIFYING CONSERVATION RELEVANT SUBGROUPS, UNDERSTANDING BASIC LIFE HISTORY AND HABITAT NEEDS, AND ASSESSING RISK OF WNS RELATED DECLINES. MANAGEMENT AGENCIES TASKED WITH MONITORING AND PROTECTING THIS SPECIES IN THE WAKE OF WNS INVASION.

THE PLPR EXISTS WITHIN THE WHITE NOSE SYNDROME RESPONSE TEAM (WNSRT) RECOGNIZED WNS FREE AREA WHERE THE FUNGUS THAT CAUSES WNS HAS YET TO BE CONFIRMED. WITH WNS RECENTLY CONFIRMED IN CLOSE PROXIMITYTO THE PLPR IT IS CRITICAL THAT THE PROPOSED LONG TERM GOALS BE ACHIEVED. THE PYRAMID LAKE NATURAL RESOURCESDEPARTMENTS (NRD) MAIN OVERARCHING GOAL IS TO DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE RESERVATION WIDE BAT INVENTORY ANDMONITORING PROGRAM TO PRESERVE ALL NATIVE BAT SPECIES ON THE PLPR. SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ARE TO BEFRAMED AROUND U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICES (USFWS) WHITE NOSE SYNDROME PROGRAM FUNDING PRIORITIES.SPECIFICALLY, WORK PLAN COMPONENTS WILL FOCUS ON  ENACTING CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR WNS VULNERABLESPECIES, INCLUDING ESTABLISHING BASELINE INFORMATION FOR VULNERABLE SPECIES  CONDUCT POPULATION MONITORING INSUPPORT OF LOCAL MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES THE NORTH AMERICAN BAT POPULATION MONITORING PROGRAM (NABAT) ANDNATIONAL GUIDELINES. THE PROJECT PERIOD GOAL IS TO IMPROVE CURRENT EFFORTS TO QUANTIFY THE COMPOSITION OF WNSVULNERABLESPECIES ON THE PLPR REGION, IMPROVE RESEARCH DESIGN AND DATA VALIDITY, AND PROMOTE BATCONSERVATION.

THE YUROK TRIBE WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (YTWD) MONITORS WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND CONDUCTS MANAGEMENT TO CONSERVEWILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS ON TRIBAL LANDS. MONITORING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IS NECESSARY FOR MANAGING INVASIVEDISEASE AGENTS, SUCH AS PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS (PD), THE CAUSE OF WHITE NOSE SYNDROME (WNS) IN NORTHAMERICAN BATS. THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) IDENTIFIED THE NEED FOR MONITORING BAT POPULATIONS TOASSESS STATUSES AND TRENDS THROUGH THE NABAT PARTNERSHIP TO COMBAT WNS. THE YTWD PROPOSES TO CONTINUE MONITORINGBAT POPULATIONS FOR AN ADDITIONAL YEAR ON YUROK LANDS WHILE BUILDING AND MAINTAINING THE LONG TERM STAFF CAPACITY NEEDED TO CONDUCT BAT MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT IN SUPPORT OF WNS MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT.THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL SUPPORT AND BUILD UPON PRIOR YTWD EFFORTS TO IDENTIFY BAT SPECIES COMPOSITION OF THE AREA, ESTABLISH A BASELINE FOR LONG TERM MONITORING, AND MONITOR FOR CHANGES IN BAT POPULATIONS OVER TIME. THE YTWD IS CURRENTLY MONITORING ONE HIGH PRIORITY NABAT CELL AS WELL AS FOUR ADDITIONAL CELLS ENCOMPASSING A LARGE SEGMENT OF TRIBAL LANDS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE  (1) PLANNING AND CONDUCTING STATIONARY AND MOBILE ACOUSTIC MONITORING SURVEYS IN THE FIVE CELLS IN 2023 PER THE NABAT PROTOCOLS  (2) BUILDING TRIBAL CAPACITY TO CONDUCT THE WORK  (3) ENGAGING WITH REGIONAL RESEARCHERS ON WHITE NOSE SYNDROME RESPONSE  AND (4) COORDINATING THE ANALYSIS OF DATA VIA AN EXISTING CONTRACT WITH BAT CONSERVATION INTERNATIONAL, AND SUBMISSION OF ACOUSTIC MONITORING DATA TO NABAT THROUGH THE PACWEST NABAT HUB,. THIS PROJECT WOULD FACILITATE CONTINUED MONITORING OF FIVE NABAT CELLS, AND SUPPORT STAFF EXPERTISE, PARTNERSHIP BUILDING AND MAINTENANCE, AND ENGAGEMENT WITH THE WNS NATIONAL RESPONSE TEAM. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE THE TRIBE, USFWS, NABAT, AND THE PACWEST NABAT HUB WITH IMPORTANT BASELINE INFORMATION ON BAT POPULATIONS IN THE REGION, WHICH IS NECESSARY TO PREPARE FOR THE ADVANCE OF WNS AND ULTIMATELY IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES TO PROTECT BAT POPULATIONS.

WHITE NOSE SYNDROME (WNS) WAS DISCOVERED IN WASHINGTON IN SPRING OF 2016, PUTTING THE SPECIES RICH BAT COMMUNITIES OF WESTERN NORTH AMERICA AT SERIOUS RISK. TO DATE, MOST CHEMICAL OR BIOLOGICAL TREATMENTS UNDER EVALUATION FOR WNS DISEASE MANAGEMENT INVOLVE SPRAYING BATS OR THEIR SUBSTRATES WITH ANTI FUNGAL AGENTS WITHIN WNS AFFECTED HIBERNACULA. HOWEVER, THE WINTER ECOLOGY OF MOST BAT SPECIES IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST OF NORTH AMERICA REMAINS POORLY OR COMPLETELY UNKNOWN, MAKING THOSE APPROACHES OF UNCERTAIN EFFECTIVENESS. AN ALTERNATIVE STRATEGY IS TO TARGET MATERNITY COLONIES FOR WHICH AN INCREASING NUMBER OF LOCATIONS ARE BEING IDENTIFIED IN WASHINGTON. THERE IS INCREASING EVIDENCE THAT WING MICROBIOMES CAN PLAY A SUBSTANTIAL ROLE IN WNS SUSCEPTIBILITY, THEREFORE ENHANCING THE WING MICROFLORA OF THESE BATS DURING THE SUMMER WITH ANTI PD BACTERIA MAY REDUCE THE IMPACT OF WNS. WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, WILDLIFE CONSERVATION SOCIETY CANADA, AND WOODLAND PARK ZOO WILL COLLABORATE ON THIS PROJECT TO IMPLEMENT WNS PROBIOTIC PROPHYLAXIS AT 6 LITTLE BROWN BAT AND YUMA MYOTIS MATERNITY ROOSTS DURING THE SUMMERS OF 2023 AND 2024.THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THIS TREATMENT TO ENHANCE SURVIVAL OF WNS SUSCEPTIBLE BAT SPECIES.

FUNDS FROM THIS GRANT WILL ALLOW US TO CONTINUE BAT POPULATION MONITORING, DISEASE SURVEILLANCE, PARTICIPATE IN WNS RELATED RESEARCH, MONITOR IMPORTANT SITES FOR POTENTIAL DISTURBANCE (GATE DESTRUCTION), AND CONTRIBUTE DATA TO REGIONAL AND NATIONAL BAT CONSERVATION EFFORTS. POPULATION AND DISEASE MONITORING WILL NOT ONLY HELP US BETTER UNDERSTAND THE IMPACT OF WNS ON BAT POPULATIONS IN MICHIGAN, BUT WILL ALSO GUIDE CONSERVATION ACTIONS NEEDED TO BENEFIT BATS. INFORMATION GATHERED THROUGH SURVEYS WILL ALSO ALLOW US TO IDENTIFY HIBERNACULA IN WHICH TO PARTNER WITH RESEARCHERS AND IDENTIFY HIBERNACULA THAT NEED FURTHER PROTECTION.

MOUNTING EVIDENCE SUGGESTS FAT STORES, PARTICULARLY PRE HIBERNATION FAT LEVELS, MAY CONTRIBUTE TO SUCCESSFUL TOLERANCE OF THE DISEASE WHITE NOSE SYNDROME (WNS) IN BATS. FAT RESERVES, PARTICULARLY AT THE START OF HIBERNATION, MAY BE ASSOCIATED WITH BEING BETTER ABLE TO SURVIVE THE ENERGETIC COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH WNS   THE BATS  ABILITY TO TOLERATE WNS. GENETIC FACTORS HAVE ALSO BEEN IMPLICATED AS CONTRIBUTING TO INCREASED SURVIVAL OF SOME INDIVIDUALS WITHIN A SPECIES, INCLUDING GENES LIKELY ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASED FAT STORES. HOWEVER, NO ASSOCIATION HAS YET BEEN MADE DIRECTLY BETWEEN INCREASED FAT RESERVES AND GENETICS. IN ADDITION, THERE IS ALSO EVIDENCE THAT GENES ASSOCIATED WITH DISEASE RESISTANCE (E.G., IMMUNE RESPONSE) MAY ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO WNS SURVIVAL OUTCOMES. THE PROPOSED WORK SEEKS TO ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING QUESTIONS.1) IS BODY MASS INDEX (BMI) INFLUENCED BY GENETICS, AND IF SO, TO WHAT (PERCENT) EXTENT 2) IS OVERALL BODY SIZE INFLUENCED BY GENETICS, AND IF SO TO WHAT (PERCENT) EXTENT 3) FOR EACH OF THE ABOVE, WHAT IS THE ESTIMATED PERCENT REDUCTION IN WNS MORTALITY COMPARED TO THE BASELINE POPULATION 4) ARE BOTH DISEASE RESISTANCE VERSUS TOLERANCE GENES UNDER SELECTION, AND IF SO, DOES THE STRENGTH OF SELECTION TEND TO BE HIGHER FOR ONE GROUP VERSUS THE OTHER  (ASSESSING RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF TOLERANCE VERSUS RESISTANCE MECHANISMS).5) IS THE STRENGTH OF THE ADVANTAGE FOR BENEFICIAL GENES (AS MEASURED BY THE ESTIMATED SELECTIVE STRENGTH) LESS PRONOUNCED IN MORE SOUTHERN POPULATIONS (I.E., IN AREAS WHICH EXPERIENCE LESS PRONOUNCED WINTERS) THE EMPHASIS IS ON ADDRESSING KNOWLEDGE GAPS THAT ARE KEY FOR CONTEXTUALIZING PREVIOUS RESERACH.

INFORMATION ON WINTER BEHAVIOR OF TEMPERATE VESPERTILIONID BATS IN MEXICO IS STILL LIMITED. CONSIDERING THE CURRENT TRENDS OF PD FUNGUS TO SOUTHERN LATITUDES IN NORTH AMERICA, IT IS EXPECTED THAT PD WILL BE DETECTED SOON IN MEXICAN TERRITORY. GIVEN THAT MEXICO HOLDS THE SOUTHERNMOST HIBERNATING BATS IN NORTH AMERICA, A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF HIBERNATION AS WELL AS CONTINUOUS SURVEILLANCE OF MEXICAN BAT POPULATIONS AND PD SURVEYS MUST BE CONSIDERED IN WHITE NOSE SYNDROME RESPONSE EFFORTS. THANKS TO THE SUPPORT AND COLLABORATION OF NATIONAL WILDLIFE HEALTH CENTER (NWHC), WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT INSTITUTE (WMI) AND FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS), DURING OUR FIVE YEARS OF EVALUATION WE WERE ABLE TO EXPLORE MORE THAN 150 AND WE FOUND 78 WINTER ROOSTS WITH HIBERNATING BATS OF 10 VESPERTILIONID SPECIES, LOCATED IN 21 SITES IN 11 STATES OF NORTHERN AND CENTRAL MEXICO. WE ALSO CONDUCTED PD SAMPLING IN 19 OF THESE SITES AND WE OBTAINED RELEVANT DATA ON WINTER COLONY COUNTS, BAT SKIN TEMPERATURES AND ADJACENT SUBSTRATE TEMPERATURES WHERE BATS ROOST, AND ROOSTING BEHAVIOR AND MOVEMENTS OF THE ENDEMIC AND ENDANGERED BAT MYOTIS PLANICEPS PRIOR TO WINTER.FOR THIS PROPOSAL, OUR GOALS ARE TO DOCUMENT THE ECOLOGY OF HIBERNATING BATS IN MEXICO AND ASSESS THE POTENTIAL ENTRY AND INVASION PROGRESS OF PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS (PD) INTO MEXICAN TERRITORY. THEREFORE, WE WILL CONTINUE WITH WINTER COLONY COUNTS AND WILL SEARCH FOR NEW BAT HIBERNACULA IN MEXICO, WITH THE DOCUMENTATION OF PHYSICAL AND ECOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS IN HIBERNACULA, AND WITH THE SEARCHING OF WINTER ROOSTS OF MYOTIS PLANICEPS. IN ADDITION, WE ARE MOTIVATING TO TWO UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO PERFORM THESIS IN THIS PROJECT, WHOM WILL BE IN CHARGE OF TO COMPARE ECOLOGICAL FEATURES BETWEEN HIBERNATING BAT POPULATIONS IN CENTRAL MEXICO AND THOSE AFFECTED BY PD FUNGUS IN NORTH AMERICA, AND TO EXPLORE THE ASSOCIATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECOLOGICAL FEATURES WITH SEASONAL AND SPATIAL VARIATIONS IN THE USE OF CAVES BY HIBERNATING BATS IN CENTRAL MEXICO. WE WILL CONTINUE WITH THE MONITORING OF THE PRESENCE ABSENCE OF PD IN HIBERNATING BATS OF MEXICO IN KNOWN SITES AND EXPAND IT TO NEW SITES.THE RELEVANT OUTCOMES WILL BE TWO UNDERGRADUATE THESES, REPORTS OF RESULTS OF THE PRESENCE ABSENCE OF PD FUNGUS IN MEXICO, AND A MANUSCRIPT ABOUT WINTER BEHAVIOR OF MYOTIS PLANICEPS. WE HAVE BEEN TRAINING AND COLLABORATING WITH PEOPLE FROM THESE ORGANIZATIONS FOR THE LAST FOUR YEARS, AND WE WILL CONTINUE TO WORK WITH THEM, AND TO INVITE OTHER KEY PARTICIPANTS FROM OTHER GOVERNMENTAL AND NON GOVERNMENTAL INSTITUTIONS, LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCIES AND INTERESTED RESEARCH GROUPS. WE WILL MEET WITH LOCAL AND GOVERNMENT AUTHORITIES SO WE CAN KEEP MAKING AN IMPACT ON DECISION MAKING OVER THE AREAS WHERE WE HAVE FOUND HIBERNACULA TO DATE. THANK TO INTERNATIONAL COLLABORATION AND TRAJECTORY OF OUR RESEARCH, THE CURRENT PROPOSAL WILL CONTINUE CONTRIBUTING TO UNDERSTANDING THE WINTER BEHAVIOR OF HIBERNATING BATS, AS WELL AS EXPANDING THE SCOPE AND THE SCALE OF THE NATIONAL RESPONSE TO WNS, IN AN EFFORT TO REDUCE, CONTAIN, OR CONTROL THE PRESENCE, TRANSMISSION, AND INFECTION OF PD IN MEXICO.

WHITE NOSE SYNDROME (WNS) IS A DISEASE OF BATS THAT HAS SPREAD ACROSS THE UNITED STATES AND CANADA OVER THE PAST 16 YEARS, DEVASTATING BAT POPULATIONS AS IT HAS ARRIVED IN NEW SITES. THE SOUTHWESTERN UNITED STATES IS CURRENTLY AT THE LEADING EDGE OF THE INVASION OF THE FUNGAL PATHOGEN RESPONSIBLE FOR THIS DISEASE, PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS (PD). OUR SAMPLING IN THIS REGION OVER THE PAST DECADE HAS DOCUMENTED THIS ADVANCING FRONT OF PD, FIRST STARTING WITH INFECTIONS IN OKLAHOMA AND TEXAS AND THEN SPREADING TO BATS IN NEW MEXICO, ARIZONA, AND CALIFORNIA. YET, THE ARRIVAL OF PD IN THE SOUTHWEST HAS NOT MEANT THE CONCOMITANT EMERGENCE OF THE DISEASE WNS, AS MOST BATS SAMPLED IN THE REGION TO DATE HAVE LIMITED TO NO SIGNS OF SKIN INFECTION OR DISEASE. THE TYPICAL WNS DISEASE PROGRESSION THAT WE AND OTHERS HAVE DOCUMENTED IN THE EAST, MIDWEST, AND IN SEVERAL CANADIAN PROVINCES IS PD ARRIVAL FOLLOWED BY WNS EMERGENCE 1 TO 3 YEARS AFTER FIRST DETECTION OF THE FUNGUS. IN CONTRAST, SOUTHWESTERN BATS APPEAR TO HAVE A DELAYED PROGRESSION OF DISEASE WITH NO SIGNS OF WNS FOUR OR MORE YEARS AFTER PD ARRIVAL. HOWEVER, PD IS STILL A RELATIVELY RECENT ARRIVAL, AND UNDERSTANDING THE FULL EXTENT OF WNS DYNAMICS IN THE SOUTHWEST ARE ONLY IN BEGINNING. OUR PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE THIS APPARENT DELAYED PROGRESSION OF WNS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE INVASION DYNAMICS OF THIS DISEASE IN SOUTHWESTERN BATS AND DETERMINE WHAT FACTORS MAY BE ENABLING THESE BATS TO PERSIST DESPITE INFECTION BY PD.
SURVEY EQUIPMENT AND DECONTAMINATION MATERIALS FOR WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME SURVEILLANCE, OUTREACH, AND BAT POPULATION MONITORING IN MISSOURI - S11TW1

THE DNR IS REQUESTING FUNDS TO ADDRESS THE 2022 FEDERAL PARTNER PRIORITIES TO FULFILL INFORMATION NEEDS, TO IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS FOR WNS AND SUSCEPTIBLE BAT SPECIES, AND ACTIVELY ENGAGE IN THE NATIONAL RESPONSE TO WNS. SPECIFICALLY, THE DNR IS SEEKING  49,739 FOR ONGOING IMPLEMENTATION OF THE WNS MANAGEMENT PROGRAM IN IOWA THROUGH CONTINUED MONITORING, DISEASE SURVEILLANCE AND BUILDING LOCAL EXPERTISE AND PARTNERSHIPS FOR LONG-TERM CAPACITY FOR MONITORING BATS. GRANT FUNDS WILL ALSO SUPPORT DNR TRAVEL TO WNS NATIONAL WORKSHOP OR THE MIDWEST BAT WORKING GROUP MEETING IN 2023.

THE FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED SUMMIT LAKE PAIUTE TRIBE  SLPT, TRIBE  MANAGES JUST OVER 14,000 ACRES OF SAGEBRUSH STEPPE IN A REMOTE AREA OF HUMBOLDT COUNTY IN NORTHWESTERN NEVADA. ALL OF THE TRIBE S DEPARTMENTS SHARE ONE MISSION  TO UNDERSTAND, CONSERVE, AND PROTECT THE RESERVATION S MYRIAD NATURAL RESOURCES. TO FURTHER THIS MISSION, WE ARE REQUESTING FUNDING TO CONTINUE OUR BAT INVENTORY AND MONITORING PROJECT FIRST INITIATED IN 2020 AS FUNDED WITH USFWS FISCAL YEAR 2019 WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME GRANTS TO STATES AND TRIBES. CONCERNING THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY, THE NEVADA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM  2022  ESTIMATES THAT HUMBOLDT COUNTY SUPPORTS THE PRESENCE OF THIRTEEN BAT SPECIES, ALL OF WHICH ARE LISTED AS BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM  SENSITIVE SPECIES. HOWEVER, THERE IS LITTLE INFORMATION REGARDING SPECIES COMPOSITION OF BAT POPULATIONS PRESENT ON OR NEAR THE SUMMIT LAKE PAIUTE RESERVATION  RESERVATION . THE TRIBE IS, THEREFORE, REQUESTING FUNDS TO CONTINUE A COMPREHENSIVE BAT POPULATION INVENTORY AND MONITORING PROGRAM  PROJECT  ON TRIBAL AND ADJACENT BLM MANAGED LANDS, AS THERE ARE NO OTHER NON-FEDERALLY FUNDED ACTIVITIES FOR BAT CONSERVATION RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT THAT ARE BEING CONDUCTED BY THE TRIBE. THE TRIBE PROPOSES TO CONTINUE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE FOLLOWING LISTED CONSERVATION PRIORITY AS THE FOUNDATION OF THE TRIBAL PROJECT  CONDUCT POPULATION MONITORING AND DISEASE SURVEILLANCE, WITH A FOCUS ON   1  DEVELOPING AND MAINTAINING LONG-TERM DATA STREAMS FOR MONITORING BATS, ESPECIALLY THROUGH USE OF WINTER AND SUMMER COLONY COUNTS, MOBILE AND STATIONARY ACOUSTICS AND CAPTURE RECORDS IN LINE WITH NABAT PROTOCOLS AND DATA ARCHIVING STANDARDS  2  PROCESSING AND UPLOADING LEGACY DATA TO NABAT FOR USE IN POPULATION ANALYSES  AND  3  PERFORMING WNS SURVEILLANCE IN CONCERT WITH NATIONAL AND STATE WNS MANAGEMENT PLANS OR PRIORITIES. BUILDING UPON THIS FOUNDATION, THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO INVENTORY AND MONITOR BAT POPULATIONS ON THE SLPT RESERVATION AND ADJOINING PUBLIC LANDS TO ASSESS STATUS AND TRENDS VIA CONTRIBUTION TO NABAT AND PERFORM WNS SURVEILLANCE VIA SWAB COLLECTION OF BAT SKIN, GUANO, HIBERNACULUM SEDIMENT, AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUBSTRATE. SATISFYING THIS GOAL WILL BENEFIT BAT SPECIES THAT ARE KNOWN, ASSUMED, OR ANTICIPATED TO BE AFFECTED BY WNS  DIRECTLY ADVANCE THE PRIORITIES OF THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY AND NATIONAL AND STATE WNS MANAGEMENT PLANS  AND BUILD UPON OR ADVANCE THE CURRENT STATE OF KNOWLEDGE OF BATS UNDER THEIR MANAGEMENT JURISDICTIONS.
CONTINUATION OF THE KEWEENAW BAY INDIAN COMMUNITY BAT MONITORING PROGRAM

TO COMBAT WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME, IDNR WILL PLACE A MINIMUM OF 10 TEMPERATURE RH DATA-LOGGERS IN MAGAZINE MINE  A MINIMUM OF 10 LOGGERS IN BIRK 2 MINE  A MINIMUM OF FIVE  5  LOGGERS IN BIRK 3 MINE  AND A MINIMUM OF FIVE  5  LOGGERS EACH IN THREE OTHER SMALLER MINES RECENTLY SURVEYED BY THE IDNR AND USFS IN FEBRUARY 2022. ADDITIONALLY, IDNR WILL USE WNS GRANT AWARD FUNDS TO PURCHASE FOUR  4  LABORATORY GRADE STANDING FREEZERS TO PROPERLY PRESERVE ALL BAT CARCASSES COLLECTED AT WIND ENERGY FACILITIES ACROSS ILLINOIS. BENEFITS INCLUDE INCREASED DATA FROM HIBERNACULA AND A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF TEMPERATURE IMPACT ON WNS. ADDITIONALLY, THE PURCHASE OF FREEZERS WILL ALLOW FOR THE PRESERVATION OF CARCASSES, WHICH COULD PROVIDE IMPORTANT DATA ON WNS IN IL THERE ARE NO EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.

THIS PROPOSED PROJECT WILL HELP GUIDE BAT CONSERVATION IN UTAH AS WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME  WNS  ESTABLISHES IN THE STATE.  THE FUNDING WILL BE USED FOR WNS DISEASE SURVEILLANCE AND DOCUMENTING WNS IMPACTS TO BAT POPULATIONS. UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE WILL USE THE INFORMATION TO WORK WITH PARTNERS TO FOCUS AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT.

NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE WILL STUDY THE RATE OF EXPANSION OF WNS, IT S ABILITY TO FLOURISH IN THE ARIDSOUTHWEST, AND HOW IT IMPACTS BAT SPECIES IN NEVADA BY  1  SAMPLING MINES AND CAVE ACROSS NEVADA FOR WNSFOLLOWING USGS NATIONAL WILDLIFE HEALTH CENTER  NWHC  WNS SAMPLING PROTOCOLS  2  ASSESSING MINES AND CAVES INNEVADA FOR HIBERNATION USE  3  CONDUCTING SPRING EMERGENCE SAMPLING FOR WNS ALSO USING NWHC PROTOCOLS  AND, 4 ENGAGING IN WNS PLANNING AT THE NATIONAL AND REGIONAL LEVELS

SPECIES CONSERVATION PLANNING IS NECESSARY TO ENSURE PERSISTENCE OF HIBERNATING BAT SPECIES THAT HAVE EXPERIENCED SEVERE POPULATION DECLINES FROM WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME (WNS). BAT CONSERVATION INTERNATIONAL WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE WNS NATIONAL RESPONSE AND THE NORTH AMERICAN BAT MONITORING PROGRAM TO USE EXISTING DATA AND ENGAGE THE RESOURCE MANAGER COMMUNITY TO DEVELOP AND OPTIMIZE HABITAT PROTECTION PRIORITIES TO ENABLE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF MYOTIS SEPTENTRIONALIS, PERIMYOTIS SUBFLAVUS, AND MYOTIS LUCIFUGUS. THE PROJECT AIMS TO BRIDGE THE GAP FROM RESEARCH AND MONITORING TO CONSERVATION PLANNING TO RESULT IN HABITAT PROTECTIONS TO AID RESILIENCY AND PROMOTE PERSISTENCE OF SMALL, REMNANT POPULATIONS OF BAT SPECIES IMPERILED BY WNS. THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL GUIDE AND PRIORITIZE CONSERVATION EFFORTS TO PROTECT AND RESTORE SITES WITH HIGHEST VALUE FOR AIDING POPULATION PERSISTENCE AND RECOVERY.

THE PENNSYLVANIA GAME COMMISSION  PGC  IS A REGIONAL LEADER IN LOCATING AND PROTECTING WINTER BAT ROOSTS, LONG TERM MONITORING OF SUMMER AND WINTER POPULATIONS, IMPLEMENTING CONSERVATION STRATEGIES, SURVEILLANCE OF WHITE NOSE SYNDROME  WNS , AND DEVELOPING NOVEL MANAGEMENT RESPONSES TO IMPROVE BAT SURVIVORSHIP AND RESILIENCE IN THE FACE OF WNS  OUR STAFF ARE SEEING EARLY SIGNS OF SUCCESS IN TREATMENT METHODS PILOTED IN PA, WHICH MAKES OUR AGENCY S WORK MORE IMPORTANT NOW THAN EVER  THE PROJECT AWARD REQUESTED IN THIS APPLICATION WILL EXPAND PGC CAPACITY TO RESPOND TO WNS BY BUILDING UPON RECENT SUCCESSES IN TREATMENT AND SURVIVOR PROTECTION, WHILE DOCUMENTING POPULATION RESPONSE BASED ON OUR LONG TERM MONITORING DATA WHICH BEGAN IN THE 1980S  THIS PROJECT AWARD WILL EXPAND PGC S CAPACITY TO  1  PROTECT THREATENED AND ENDANGERED BAT SPECIES THROUGH A FOCUSED SEARCH FOR WNS SURVIVORS  2  ESTABLISH A STATEWIDE PROGRAM TO ASSESS BAT USE OF ABANDONED MINE PORTALS  3  CONTINUE OUR PILOT EFFORTS TO LOWER INTERNAL AIR TEMPERATURE IN ABANDONED MINES TO REDUCE WNS MORTALITY  4  REFINE GROUND BREAKING TREATMENT TRIALS AT WNS IMPACTED SITES  5  PROTECT SURVIVOR SITES AND MAINTAIN HIGHEST QUALITY POPULATION DATA THROUGH DEVELOPMENT OF TWO SKILL BUILDING WORKSHOPS COVERING  CAVE GATING FOR LAND MANAGERS AND BIOLOGISTS AND BAT MIST NETTING FOR REGION BIOLOGISTS AND TECHNICIANS  6  COLLABORATE WITH WNS RESEARCHERS AND THE WNS RESPONSE PLAN GUIDANCE TO SHARE RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT RESULTS  BY SHARING OUR DATA AND STUDY OUTCOMES, PGC S WNS MANAGEMENT AND MITIGATION WORK CAN BENEFIT STATES IN THE EAST AND THROUGH THE RANGE OF WNS IMPACT

THE VIABILITY OF WASHINGTON BAT POPULATIONS CONTINUES TO BE AT RISK FROM EFFECTS OFWHITE NOSE SYNDROME  WNS   IN 2016, WNS WAS FIRST DETECTED IN WASHINGTON, AND RECENT RECORDSINDICATE INCREASING PREVALENCE IN COUNTIES ALREADY CONFIRMED WITH WNS AS WELL AS IN NEW COUNTIES WDFW PROPOSES TO CONDUCT POPULATION MONITORING AND DISEASE SURVEILLANCE TO PARTICIPATE IN ANDPROVIDE SUPPORT FOR WNS RELATED RESEARCH PROJECTS AND TO ENGAGE WITH WORKING GROUPS AND MEETINGSRELATED TO WNS AND BATS  THE OBJECTIVES IN THIS PROPOSAL WILL HELP ACHIEVE WDFW WNS RESPONSEOBJECTIVES AS WELL AS CONTRIBUTE INFORMATION TO THE NATIONAL WNS PLAN, WHICH WILL ENHANCE OUR ABILITY TOSUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENT BROAD CONSERVATION AND MITIGATION EFFORTS LEADING TO BAT POPULATION RESILIENCY INWESTERN NORTH AMERICA

THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT  DOEE  WILL USE GRANT FUNDS TO PURCHASE EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES AND TO HIRE A TECHNICIAN TO ASSIST WITH DOEE S ONGOING BAT RESEARCH  THE PURPOSE OF DOEE S WHITE NOSE SYNDROME  WNS  RESEARCH PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY AND UNDERSTAND THE EXTENT OF WNS AND LIMIT ITS PRESENCE IN THE DISTRICT  DOEE WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN REGIONAL MULTI AGENCY COLLABORATION TO DETECT THE PRESENCE OF WNS IN THE DISTRICT AS EARLY AS POSSIBLE AND ASSIST THE OTHER STATES IN THEIR EFFORTS THROUGH ATTENDANCE AT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL MEETINGS IN PERSON AND ONLINE  DOEE BIOLOGISTS WILL GATHER DATA ON BATS AND THEIR HABITATS THROUGH ACTIVE  MIST NET  AND PASSIVE  ACOUSTIC  MONITORING TO CONTINUE DOCUMENTATION OF THE LOCATION OF MATERNAL ROOSTS AND ADDITIONAL HIBERNACULA  THROUGHOUT THIS PROJECT, DOEE BIOLOGISTS SHALL ADHERE TO THE CURRENT US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE EQUIPMENT DECONTAMINATION PROTOCOLS WHEN CONDUCTING MIST NETTING SURVEYS AND ANY WORK CONDUCTED FOR BAT ROOSTS AND HIBERNACULA  ALL ACTIVITY WILL BE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE UPDATED USFWS 2023 INDIANA BAT SUMMER SURVEY GUIDELINES BY GATHERING DATA ON SPECIES OCCURRENCES IN THE DISTRICT, THE NUMBER AND LOCATION OF MATERNAL ROOSTS AND WINTER HIBERNACULA, THIS STUDY WILL ASSIST WITH THE CONSERVATION OF BATS LISTED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED, CONSERVATION OF THE FEDERALLY LISTED M  SEPTENTRIONALIS, AND THE CONSERVATION OF THE PETITIONED P  SUBFLAVUS  THROUGH THE MANAGEMENT OF CONSERVATION OF THESE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITAT, THE IMPACTS OF WNS IN THE DISTRICT MAY BE MITIGATED

MARYLAND IS A WHITE NOSE SYNDROME  WNS  AFFECTED STATE IN ITS THIRTEENTH YEAR OF EXPOSURE WITH ALL HIBERNACULA CONFIRMED POSITIVE, A DEMANDING PERIOD FOR A STATE AGENCY IN THE CYCLE OF WNS IMPACT  CONTINUING ACOUSTIC SURVEYS AND MONITORING SPECIAL HABITATS AS WNS PROGRESSES ARE IMPERATIVE TO DETERMINE LOCATIONS AND POPULATION STATUSES OF BATS IN MARYLAND  THESE ACTIVITIES PROVIDE FOR THE MAINTENANCE AND SUPPORT OF POST WNS SURVIVING BATS THROUGH DIRECT PROTECTION OF ROOSTS AND HABITAT RECOMMENDATIONS AND IMPLEMENTATION, INCLUDING BAT FRIENDLY FOREST MANAGEMENT AND PLACEMENT OF BAT BOXES  THESE DATA WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE NABAT DATABASE

SINCE 2011, THE VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT  VFWD  HAS USED WHITE NOSE SYNDROME  WNS  GRANTS TO STATES TO INCREASE VERMONTS CAPACITY FOR BUILDING AND EXPANDING A WNS MANAGEMENT PROGRAM THAT MEETS OBJECTIVES LAID OUT IN THE WNS NATIONAL PLAN  FIVE OF VERMONTS SIX CAVE HIBERNATING SPECIES ARE LISTED AS STATE THREATENED OR ENDANGERED, INCLUDING TWO ALSO FEDERALLY PROTECTED AND TWO OTHERS UNDERGOING FEDERAL STATUS ASSESSMENT  WNS HAS CAUSED POPULATION DECLINES OF OVER 90 PERCENT FOR THREE IMPACTED BAT SPECIES  THE LONG TERM, OVERARCHING GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO MONITOR AND BETTER UNDERSTAND THE IMPACTS OF WNS ON AFFECTED AND SUSCEPTIBLE BAT SPECIES AND TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES TO RECOVER THEIR POPULATIONS  WE AIM TO ACHIEVE THESE GOALS THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN THE WHITE NOSE NATIONAL PLAN, POPULATION MONITORING, INTERAGENCY COLLABORATION, PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT, AND DISSEMINATION OF GUIDANCE AND RESULTS  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CRITICAL POPULATION SURVEYS, RESEARCH COLLABORATION, DISEASE SURVEILLANCE, REDUCTION OF MORTALITY FROM NON WNS THREATS, TARGETED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND ACTIONS TO INCREASE SURVIVAL AND RECOVERY OF INFECTED BATS  ACTIVITIES ARE EXPECTED TO SUPPORT POSITIVE POPULATION GROWTH BY WORKING WITH PARTNERS TO MONITOR POPULATIONS AND IDENTIFY THE BEST LOCATIONS FOR BENEFICIAL MANAGEMENT ACTIONS  LANDOWNERS AND LAND MANAGERS HOSTING BOTH SUMMER AND WINTER COLONY SITES WILL BENEFIT FROM UNDERSTANDING CURRENT POPULATION TRENDS AND WHAT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS THEY CAN TAKE TO BENEFIT BATS AFFECTED BY WNS  POPULATION MONITORING DATA WILL BE UPLOADED TO THE NORTH AMERICAN BAT MONITORING PROJECT, WHERE RESEARCHERS CAN ACQUIRE INFORMATION FOR ANSWERING IMPORTANT QUESTIONS ABOUT WNS IMPACTS TO BAT POPULATIONS AND AGENCIES CAN ANALYZE ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION DATA TO MAKE LISTING OR DE LISTING DECISIONS AND INFORM CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY GUIDANCE

THIS PROJECT WILL HELP UNDERSTAND OREGON BAT POPULATIONS AND COMBAT THE INCURSION OF WHITE NOSE SYNDROME  WNS  BYESTABLISHING BASELINE DATA SUCH AS OCCUPANCY, HABITAT USAGE, AND ROOST CHARACTERISTICS AND SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONAND ABUNDANCE, AS WELL AS PERFORMING DISEASE SURVEILLANCE IN CONCERT WITH NATIONAL AND OREGON S WNS MANAGEMENTPLANS  ADDITIONALLY, INFORMATION REGARDING THE UTILIZATION OF REPLACEMENT BAT ROOSTS BY BATS DISPLACED FROMTRADITIONAL MATERNITY ROOST SITES IS VITAL TO UNDERSTAND PRIOR TO THE REMOVAL OF THE LOWER KLAMATH RIVERHYDROELECTRIC DAMS ODFW S AGENCY  SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO   1  ASSESS PRE WNS DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCES OFBATS IN OREGON,  2  ESTABLISH BASELINE INFORMATION ON THE PRESENCE OR ABSENCE OF WNS PD IN OREGON AND DEVELOP ASAMPLING SCHEME FOR EARLY DETECTION OF WNS PD   3  ESTABLISH A PROTOCOL FOR MANAGEMENT SHOULD WNS PD ARRIVE INOREGON, AND  4  TO PROVIDE PUBLIC OUTREACH ABOUT BATS AND THE THREATS THAT WNS POSES  THESE OBJECTIVES ARECOORDINATED WITH THE PRIORITIES OF THE NATIONAL RESPONSE TO WNS BECAUSE THEY BOLSTER NATIONAL EFFORTS TO 1 MONITOR THE SPREAD OF THE DISEASE TO POTENTIALLY MITIGATE FUTURE IMPACTS  AND 2  CONDUCT POPULATION AND DISEASESURVEILLANCE TO GUIDE LOCAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS  AND 3  DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION STRATEGIES TO HELPWNS AFFECTED OR VULNERABLE SPECIES AND POTENTIALLY MITIGATE THE IMPACTS OF WNS  AND 4  HELP TO CURTAIL ANDHOPEFULLY PREVENT THE SPREAD OF THE DISEASE THROUGH FOCUSED PUBLIC OUTREACH  ADDITIONALLY, THROUGH THE USE OFPASSIVE INTEGRATED TRANSPONDER  PIT  TAGS AND ASSOCIATED ARRAYS WITHIN REPLACEMENT BAT ROOSTS, THE STUDY WILLDETERMINE IF INDIVIDUAL BATS INHABITING EXISTING ROOST SITES MIGHT ALTERNATIVELY USE REPLACEMENT ROOSTS

NORTHERN LONG EARED BATS HAVE DECLINED DRAMATICALLY IN THE NORTHEAST, MIDWEST, AND MID ATLANTIC REGIONS DUE TO WHITE NOSE SYNDROME, PROMPTING THE LISTING AS FEDERALLY THREATENED BY THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IN 2015  RECENTLY, AND BASED ON A THOROUGH REVIEW OF THE SPECIES  STATUS, THE USFWS ANNOUNCED A PROPOSAL TO RECLASSIFY THE NORTHERN LONG EARED BAT AS ENDANGERED  DOCKET FWS R3 ES 2021 0140   THE SERVICE S REVIEW FOUND THAT WNS IS EXPECTED TO AFFECT 100  OF THE SPECIES  RANGE BY 2025, WITH ESTIMATED DECLINES OF 97 TO 100 PERCENT IN MANY POPULATIONS  WHILE POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED DRAMATICALLY THROUGHOUT THE SPECIES  RANGE, THERE ARE EXTANT POPULATIONS IN PARTS OF THE SPECIES  RANGE  IN COASTAL NORTH CAROLINA THERE ARE 24 COUNTIES WITH RECENT CAPTURE RECORDS, AND ACTIVE MATERNITY COLONIES ARE KNOWN IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, NEW YORK, PENNSYLVANIA, AND WEST VIRGINIA  EXTANT POPULATIONS HAVE BEEN DOCUMENTED IN COASTAL AND NORTHERN VIRGINIA, BUT LITTLE TO NO WORK HAS BEEN CONDUCTED IN THE SOUTHWEST REGION OF THE STATE WHERE ACOUSTIC RECORDS FOR NORTHERN LONG EARED BATS OCCUR  WORKING WITH CONSERVATION PARTNERS IN SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA WE PROPOSE TO USE ACOUSTIC SAMPLING TO FOCUS MIST NET EFFORTS IN ORDER TO CAPTURE AND RADIO TAG NORTHERN LONG EARED BATS WITH A FOCUS ON REPRODUCTIVELY ACTIVE FEMALES AND JUVENILES  INDIVIDUALS WILL BE TRACKED BACK TO MATERNITY COLONIES WHERE SITE SPECIFIC CHARACTERISTICS WILL BE QUANTIFIED ON ROOST TREE SELECTION AND SURROUNDING HABITAT  IN ADDITION WE WILL MIST NET AND RADIO TAG NORTHERN LONG EARED BATS IN LATE SUMMER TO EARLY FALL IN ORDER TO IDENTIFY WINTER ROOSTS  THIS INFORMATION WILL HELP THE VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND OUR CONSERVATION PARTNERS IDENTIFY SPECIFIC AREAS TO MANAGE AND PROTECT TO PROVIDE FOR THE SURVIVORSHIP OF NORTHERN LONG EARED BATS

THE MAINE DEPARTMENT OF INLAND FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE  MIDIFW  IS REQUESTING FUNDS FOR THE PURPOSE OF SUPPORTING ONGOING BAT RESEARCH AND MONITORING EFFORTS THAT SPECIFICALLY ADDRESS THE 2022 GRANT PRIORITIES OF CONDUCTING POPULATION MONITORING TO DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN LONG TERM DATA SETS  OF MAINE S 8 BAT SPECIES, 3 ARE LISTED UNDER MAINE S ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  LITTLE BROWN BAT  ENDANGERED   NORTHERN LONG EARED BAT  ENDANGERED AND FEDERALLY THREATENED   AND EASTERN SMALL FOOTED BAT  THREATENED   THE FIVE OTHER SPECIES ARE DESIGNATED AS SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN  TRI COLORED BAT, EASTERN RED BAT, HOARY BAT, SILVER HAIRED BAT AND BIG BROWN BAT  WITH THE RARITY OF MAINE S BATS, THE CONTINUED THREAT OF WHITE NOSE SYNDROME, AND THE EMERGING THREATS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND INCREASING ENERGY DEVELOPMENT, IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT WE CONTINUE MONITORING BAT DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE PURCHASING BAT ACOUSTIC EQUIPMENT AND CONDUCTING STATIONARY ACOUSTIC BAT SURVEYS IN A VARIETY OF HABITATS THROUGHOUT MAINE, THUS CONTRIBUTING TO MAINE S LONG TERM BAT MONITORING PROGRAM  ALL DATA WILL ALSO BE UPLOADED TO THE NABAT PROGRAM  THEREBY CONTRIBUTING TO CONTINENT WIDE MONITORING  MDIFW WILL ANALYZE ACOUSTIC RECORDINGS USING THE BAT CALL IDENTIFICATION PROGRAM KALEIDOSCOPE PRO TO DETERMINE THE SPECIES PRESENT AND THE NUMBER OF BAT PASSES DETECTED AT EACH SITE  EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE AN INCREASED KNOWLEDGE CONCERNING THE STATUS, DISTRIBUTION, AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF MAINE S BATS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE ALABAMA S WHITE NOSE SYNDROME MANAGEMENT PROGRAM  WHITE NOSE SYNDROME  WNS , A FUNGAL DISEASE THAT INFECTS HIBERNATING BATS, WAS FIRST CONFIRMED IN THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF ALABAMA IN 2012  SINCE THEN, WORK CONDUCTED BY ALABAMA WILDLIFE AND FRESHWATER FISHERIES  AWFF  HAS DOCUMENTED A  75  DECLINE IN COUNTS OF TRICOLORED BATS  PERIMYOTIS SUBFLAVUS  AT CAVES MONITORED IN NORTH ALABAMA AND A 95  DECLINE IN INDIANA BATS  MYOTIS SODALIS  AT THE STATE S TWO HISTORICALLY KNOWN HIBERNACULA  THE DISEASE HAS SPREAD SOUTHWARD TO COVER HALF THE STATE, CONTINUING TO ENCOUNTER AND THREATEN NEW POPULATIONS OF BATS  THE STATE OF ALABAMA DOES NOT EMPLOY A FULL TIME BAT BIOLOGIST AND HAS NO STAFF DEDICATED FULL TIME TO BAT CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT  DESPITE THIS, AWFF HAS MADE DEMONSTRATED CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE NATIONAL FIGHT AGAINST WNS FROM PAST FUNDING UNDER THIS GRANT PROGRAM THE ONGOING GOAL OF ALABAMA S WHITE NOSE SYNDROME MANAGEMENT PROGRAM IS TO CONSERVE THE BATS OF ALABAMA SUSCEPTIBLE TO WNS  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE BAT POPULATION MONITORING AND DISEASE SURVEILLANCE, PROVIDING LOGISTICAL SUPPORT TO WNS RESEARCH PROJECTS, AND ALLOWING AWFF STAFF TO ATTEND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES SUPPORTING THE UNDERSTANDING AND MANAGEMENT OF WNS  THE MISSION OF AWFF IS TO MANAGE, PROTECT, CONSERVE, AND ENHANCE THE WILDLIFE AND AQUATIC RESOURCES OF ALABAMA FOR THE SUSTAINABLE BENEFIT OF THE PEOPLE OF ALABAMA

FORMERLY A COMMON SPECIES, THE NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT (MYOTIS SEPTENTRIONALIS) IS NOW RARELY ENCOUNTERED THROUGHOUT MUCH OF ITS RANGE DUE TO POPULATION DECLINES FROM WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME, A FUNGAL DISEASE THAT AFFECTS HIBERNATING BATS. HOWEVER, PERSISTING POPULATIONS OF NORTHERN LONG-EARED BATS HAVE BEEN FOUND ALONG THE NORTHEAST COAST. DESPITE THEIR PERSISTENCE, THERE REMAINS A LACK OF PROTECTED HIBERNATION SITES IN THE AREA. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD HIBERNATION SITES FOR COASTAL NORTHERN LONG-EARED BATS ON CURRENTLY OCCUPIED HABITAT AND PROTECTED LAND, PROVIDING SPACES THAT ARE PROTECTED FROM FUTURE DEVELOPMENT AND DISTURBANCE. THIS PROJECT WILL OCCUR ON MARTHA'S VINEYARD, NANTUCKET, AND LONG ISLAND. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE CONSTRUCTION OF NEW HIBERNATION SITES, USE OF LURES TO DRAW BATS TO THE SITES, AND MONITORING BAT USE OF THE SITES USING ACOUSTIC BAT DETECTORS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT OF A MANAGEMENT TOOL (I.E. A CONSTRUCTED HIBERNATION SITE) THAT CAN BE USED TO IMPROVE SURVIVAL OF HIBERNATING BATS WITH A LOW-COST AND RELATIVELY SIMPLE DESIGN. THIS LONG-TERM STRATEGY CAN BE USED FOR CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT BY WILDLIFE MANAGERS ACROSS THE ISLANDS TO SUPPORT PERSISTENCE OF THESE UNIQUE COASTAL POPULATION, ENSURING THE SURVIVAL OF HIBERNATING COASTAL MYSE.

SINCE 2006, WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME HAS CAUSED LARGE DECLINES IN POPULATIONS OF HIBERNATING BATS IN NORTH AMERICA. THE LITTLE BROWN BAT (MYOTIS LUCIFUGUS) POPULATION IN THE NORTHEAST HAS DECLINED BY >90% BUT SEEMS TO HAVE STABILIZED IN RECENT YEARS. BATS THAT SURVIVE WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME INFECTION DURING WINTER HIBERNATION CONTINUE TO BE IMPACTED BY THIS DISEASE INTO THE SPRING AND SUMMER MONTHS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE FACTORS THAT AFFECT LITTLE BROWN BAT RECOVERY FROM WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME AND EXPLORE DIFFERENT RATES OF RECOVERY AMONG COLONIES. SPECIFICALLY, GUANO (BAT POOP) WILL BE COLLECTED FROM THREE LITTLE BROWN BAT MATERNITY COLONIES IN MASSACHUSETTS, TWO IN NEW HAMPSHIRE, AT LEAST FOUR IN MANITOBA/ONTARIO, AND AT LEAST FOUR IN WASHINGTON DURING THE SPRING AND SUMMER. GUANO SAMPLES WILL BE USED TO ASSESS STRESS, IMMUNE GENE EXPRESSION, AND VIRUS TYPE AND LEVELS AT THE MATERNITY COLONIES IDENTIFIED FOR THE STUDY. THIS INFORMATION WILL THEN BE USED TO BUILD A MODEL TO ESTIMATE THE FUTURE GROWTH RATES OF THE COLONIES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE PREDICTIONS OF HOW BATS ARE RESPONDING TO WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME AND THE LIKELIHOOD THAT A BAT WILL BE PART OF A SLOWLY RECOVERING OR SUCCESSFULLY RECOVERING COLONY. THIS WILL HELP INFORM WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS ABOUT WHICH COLONIES MAY NEED MORE PROTECTION OR WHICH COLONIES WOULD BENEFIT FROM DIRECT INTERVENTION, SUCH AS A TREATMENT. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK INCLUDE STATE AND OTHER WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS.
WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME GRANTS TO STATES AND TRIBES, FISCAL YEAR 2021 -- MINNESOTA PROPOSAL

WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME, A FUNGAL DISEASE THAT AFFECTS HIBERNATING BATS, HAS CAUSED EXTREME DECLINES IN BAT POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT NORTH AMERICA. THE FUNGUS THAT CAUSES WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME CONTINUES TO SPREAD INTO ARID REGIONS OF THE WESTERN UNITED STATES, WHERE BATS ARE ALREADY UNDER STRESS FROM DROUGHT. IN ADDITION, GLOBAL DECLINES IN INSECT POPULATIONS RAISE CONCERNS THAT REDUCED PREY RESOURCES COULD FURTHER IMPACT BAT POPULATIONS. DURING THE FALL, BEFORE BATS ENTER HIBERNATION, THEY MUST HAVE ACCESS TO HIGH-QUALITY PREY IN ORDER TO ACQUIRE SUFFICIENT FAT STORES TO SURVIVE WINTER HIBERNATION. BATS THAT ARE IMPACTED BY WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME USE THEIR FAT STORES FASTER THAN HEALTHY BATS. THEREFORE, IMPROVING FORAGING HABITAT TO ENHANCE PREY QUALITY MAY AID SURVIVAL AND RECOVERY OF BAT POPULATIONS AFFECTED BY WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME. THIS APPROACH OFFERS LONG-TERM CONSERVATION VALUE THAT COULD BE WIDELY IMPLEMENTED. THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD UPON AN EXISTING HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT TO ANSWER QUESTIONS ABOUT HOW HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS CAN BENEFIT BAT POPULATIONS IN THE WEST. SPECIFICALLY, RESEARCHERS WILL DETERMINE IF THE RESTORATION OF DESERT SPRINGS IMPROVES PREY QUALITY AND QUANTITY AND BAT FORAGING ACTIVITY. BAT CONSERVATION INTERNATIONAL WILL WORK IN COLLABORATION WITH THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT AND BAT CONSERVATION INTERNATIONAL'S HABITAT PROTECTION AND RESTORATION PROGRAM TO COMPLETE THIS PROJECT. THE PROJECT WILL BE CONDUCTED AT APPROXIMATELY SIX DESERT SPRINGS SITES (THREE RESTORED AND THREE UNRESTORED CONTROL SITES) MANAGED BY THE HASSAYAMPA FIELD OFFICE OF THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT IN ARIZONA. INSECTS WILL BE SAMPLED EACH NIGHT FOR A WEEK, FIVE TIMES PER YEAR, FOR THE DURATION OF THE TWO-YEAR STUDY. CAPTURED INSECTS WILL BE GROUPED BY SIZE AND IDENTIFIED TO ORDER TO ASSESS THE QUALITY OF AVAILABLE PREY. BAT ACTIVITY AND FORAGING RATES WILL ALSO BE EVALUATED USING ACOUSTIC DETECTORS PLACED AT EACH SITE. RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL HELP DEVELOP EFFECTIVE LONG-TERM STRATEGIES TO BUILD RESILIENCY FOR BATS FACED WITH DROUGHT, ARIDITY, AND WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME INVASION IN WESTERN LANDSCAPES.
MONITORING A SUMMER COLONY OF MYOTIS LUCIFUGUS IN OHIO

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND RESEARCH AND CONSERVATION THAT SUPPORTS MANAGEMENT OF WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME AND BAT CONSERVATION. WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME IS A FUNGAL DISEASE AFFECTING HIBERNATING BATS THAT WAS DISCOVERED IN WASHINGTON DURING THE SPRING OF 2016. THIS DISEASE PUTS THE DIVERSE BAT COMMUNITIES OF WESTERN NORTH AMERICA AT SERIOUS RISK. TO DATE, MOST TREATMENTS UNDER EVALUATION FOR WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME DISEASE MANAGEMENT INVOLVE SPRAYING CHEMICAL OR BIOLOGICAL AGENTS ONTO BATS OR SURFACES WHERE BATS HIBERNATE, DURING THE WINTER, WITHIN WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME AFFECTED SITES. HOWEVER, THE WINTER ECOLOGY OF MOST BAT SPECIES IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST REMAINS POORLY OR COMPLETELY UNKNOWN, WHICH INTRODUCES UNCERTAINTY IN THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THESE TREATMENT APPROACHES FOR BATS IN THIS REGION. AS AN ALTERNATIVE STRATEGY, THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO TARGET SUMMER MATERNITY COLONIES FOR WHICH AN INCREASING NUMBER OF LOCATIONS ARE BEING IDENTIFIED IN WASHINGTON. THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO 1) LOCATE AND MONITOR ADDITIONAL MATERNITY COLONIES IN WASHINGTON AND 2) REDUCE THE SEVERITY OF WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME ON VULNERABLE SPECIES OF BATS IN WASHINGTON BY TESTING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF A NEW TREATMENT APPROACH AT MATERNITY COLONIES. THERE IS INCREASING EVIDENCE THAT COMMUNITIES OF BACTERIA FOUND NATURALLY ON THE WINGS OF BATS CAN PLAY A ROLE IN THE SEVERITY OF WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME DISEASE. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO APPLY NATURALLY OCCURRING BENEFICIAL BACTERIA TO THE WINGS OF BATS TO IMPROVE THEIR ABILITY TO COMBAT WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME AND REDUCE THE DEVASTATING IMPACTS OF THE DISEASE. TO DO THIS, WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE WILL COLLABORATE WITH WILDLIFE CONSERVATION SOCIETY CANADA TO FIND AND DESCRIBE NEW MATERNITY COLONY SITES. SPECIES AT EACH SITE WILL BE IDENTIFIED, COUNTED, MONITORED FOR IMPACTS OF WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME, AND ROOST TYPE WILL BE DESCRIBED. APPROXIMATELY SIX TO EIGHT SITES WILL BE CHOSEN FOR TREATMENT TESTING DURING THE SUMMERS OF 2022 AND 2023. AT EACH TREATMENT SITE, BENEFICIAL BACTERIA WILL BE MIXED INTO A POWDERED CLAY AND APPLIED TO THE SURFACES OF BAT BOXES AND OTHER MATERNITY ROOST STRUCTURES WHILE BATS ARE NOT PRESENT. WHEN BATS ENTER THE STRUCTURES, THE BENEFICIAL BACTERIA AND CLAY MIXTURE WILL TRANSFER ONTO THEIR WINGS AND FUR, ENHANCING THEIR NATURAL BACTERIAL COMMUNITY. RESEARCHERS WILL EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE TREATMENT STRATEGY BY DOCUMENTING AND COMPARING SURVIVORSHIP OF MARKED INDIVIDUALS IN AREAS THAT ARE POSITIVE FOR WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME AND EVALUATING COLONY SIZE TRENDS OVER THE STUDY PERIOD. THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE INFORMATION ABOUT MATERNITY COLONY TYPES, SPECIES ASSEMBLAGES, AND WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME IMPACTS IN WASHINGTON AS WELL AS DETERMINE EFFICACY OF A TREATMENT APPROACH THAT TARGETS SUMMER MATERNITY COLONIES USING BENEFICIAL BACTERIA. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A FRAMEWORK TO IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE SEVERAL WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME TREATMENT OPTIONS IN THE FUTURE.
